required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Infra Red Vein Visualization: Efficacy vs. Standard Technique
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized Controlled Study of Efficacy of Infra Red Vein Illumination Versus Standard Technique

brief_summary.textblock: The objective of the study is to assess the efficacy of the vein visualization device AccuVein (AccuVein, Inc., Huntington, NY) in comparison to a standard technique for establishing intravenous (iv) access in the infant and toddler population (<2years)

detailed_description.textblock: The objective of this project is to compare the iv success rate using the FDA approved Accuvein device for vein illumination versus not using the device, for infants/toddlers undergoing surgery at Penn State Children's Hospital with an ASA physical status 1, 2, or 3. After obtaining informed consent, the infant will be randomized to the vein illuminatin or standard group based on a computer generated number.

primary_outcome.time_frame: When patient is in operating room and insertion of intravenous access line has been confirmed to be successful
primary_outcome.description: Success for insertion of intravenous access line will be determined by flushability with 5 ml of sterile normal saline

secondary_outcome.time_frame: When patient is in operating room and insertion of intravenous access line is performed
secondary_outcome.description: The number of attempts it takes for successful insertion of the intravenous access line

secondary_outcome.time_frame: When patient is in operating room and insertion of intravenous access line is performed
secondary_outcome.description: The time to successful insertion of the intravenous access line will be measured from the first time that the canula touches the skin to until successful iv access is established

arm_group.description: Infrared illumination of veins, using the FDA approved AccuVein device, will be used to assist in vein location when inserting an intravenous access line
Standard vein location techniques will be used when inserting an intravenous access line

intervention.description: Infrared illumination of veins using the FDA approved AccuVein (AccuVein, Inc., Huntington, NY) device.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Children(<2year) undergoing anesthesia procedures at Penn State Health, Hershey Medical Center and Penn State Children's Hospital
2. ASA physical status 1,2 or 3
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Emergency procedures requiring anesthesia
2. ASA physical status 4
3. Patients with pre existing iv access
